Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Boolean Microgrid

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Boolean Microgrid (BM) emulates the Internet by supplying discrete power and discrete data over a network link that follows Boolean logic and is not continuous as in a conventional 60-Hz-ac or dc microgrid. BM is thus a highly integrated cyber-physical system (CPS) that features the convergence of control, communication and the physical plant. BMs realization poses the following research challenges that we plan to address: a) what is the most efficient, economic, power-dense, and reliable way of integrating the distributed energy sources and loads to the BM, and the BM to the utility grid, using power-electronic interfaces for seamless and on-demand distributed power delivery? b) what is the control-communication mechanism that optimizes BM nodal and network control performances under conditions of varying power generation and load demand and communication-network throughput and reliability? Our unique approaches to address these research challenges will encompass novel mechanisms based on high-frequency-link power conversion, dynamic-pricing based optimal network capacity and resource utilization, event-triggered sampling and communication, and optimal switching-sequence control.
BM has the potential to influence next-generation systems including smart grid, vehicular microgrid, electric ships, military microgrid, electric aircraft, telecommunication systems, and residential, commercial, and critical-infrastructure (e.g., hospital) power systems. On the educational front, the proposed project will provide graduate- and post-graduate-level education to four researchers. Further, multiple undergraduate (including minority) students and middle-school students will be provided research/educational opportunities. The results of the research will be integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses at the collaborating universities including a dedicated course on CPS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Increased utilization of renewable energy sources such as wind or solar power necessitates that loads be responsive to generation, a strategy called "demand response." One way to do so is to take advantage of the flexibility resulting from pooling demand. This can be done by an intermediary such as a load serving entity that caters to a large number of loads. However, privacy of loads has recently emerged as an important issue, and it has become important that demand response be performed without the loads having to reveal their states to the load serving entity. We have shown how such privacy-respecting demand response can be done in a tractable manner for a collection of inertial thermal loads. This provides a potential solution for a business model for load serving entities.

 The operation of charging stations for electric vehicles (EVs) requires addressing of multiple coupled issues including purchase, storage, pricing and scheduling. Energy may need to purchased at times when the real-time prices are low and stored. Such storage may also be important in meeting peak demand without overloading the distribution system. Storage is however subject to capacity constraints as well as round-trip loss due to charging and discharging. The charging of electric vehicles will need to be optimized over time since users may have deadline constraints. Price differentiation may need to be used to separate users with tight deadlines from those with more flexibility. Electric vehicle charging stations will need to perform all these coupled optimizations. We have developed a decomposition that is layered by time-scale to handle this overall problem. In the top layer, a deterministic pricing scheme for EV customers is developed by considering the long-term average grid power price and availability of renewable energy, plus price-demand curves for different types of energy requests with different relative deadlines. In the middle layer, we have developed an optimal policy to determine the amounts of energy to buy from the grid and to use for charging in successive time intervals. We have modeled customer arrivals as stochastic processes modulated by the price determined by the top layer and announced to customers. In the bottom layer, we have addressed the problem of fulfilling all charging requests without missing deadlines by prioritizing requests with earlier deadlines, and using the optimal charging scheme derived in the middle layer. This three-layer decomposition provides a tractable and holistic solution.

 We have addressed the problem of how a system operator can optimize the social welfare of an overall system consisting of many types of generators and loads. Individual loads and generators may not wish to share information about their dynamic models, their costs of operation or uncertainties with the system operator. Further, even they did, this would be such a huge dimensional system that would be intractable for the system operator to manage. Such a system, reminiscent of general equilibrium theory, therefore needs to be coordinated and optimized through prices. We have designed a bid-price iteration scheme so that the system operator can ensure that the overall dynamically time-varying power system consisting of several loads and generators that are subject to uncertainties due to wind or temperature or price of fuel will be operated over time so as to realize optimal social welfare.
